text:
I created a cash out function which, using the sizeBack, priceBack and priceLay variables, calculates the sizeLay to cash out at 0.

It happens, however, that if I open an order in LAY for example at 1.72 (to have a balanced output on all lines), I find myself instead a LAY at odd lower than about 4 ticks.

How can I open (reserve) a LAY to a specific odds without being assigned the best one at the moment?

elements.text:
I created a cash out function which, using the sizeBack, priceBack and priceLay variables, calculates the sizeLay to cash out at 0.

It happens, however, that if I open an order in LAY for example at 1.72 (to have a balanced output on all lines), I find myself instead a LAY at odd lower than about 4 ticks.

How can I open (reserve) a LAY to a specific odds without being assigned the best one at the moment?

text:
I'm currently editing the examplestreaminghistorical.py file in BFLW to output a little more data. I've figured out most of what I need, but can't for the life of me find the last traded value. Of course the last_price_traded for each runner is already there, but where do I find the actual amount traded? I think it corresponds to the TRD value in the BF historical data file.

```runner_def = runners_dict.get(
                    (runner.selection_id, runner.handicap))
                output.write(
                    "%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s\n"
                    % (
                        market_book.market_id,
                        market_book.publish_time,
                        market_book.status,
                        market_book.inplay,
                        market_book.total_matched,
                        runner.selection_id,
                        runner.ex.available_to_back[0].price,
                        runner.ex.available_to_back[0].size,
                        runner.ex.available_to_lay[0].price,
                        runner.ex.available_to_lay[0].size,
                        runner.total_matched,
                        runner.last_price_traded or "",
                    )
                )```

elements.text: I'm currently editing the examplestreaminghistorical.py file in BFLW to output a little more data. I've figured out most of what I need, but can't for the life of me find the last traded value. Of course the last_price_traded for each runner is already there, but where do I find the actual amount traded? I think it corresponds to the TRD value in the BF historical data file.

runner_def = runners_dict.get(
                    (runner.selection_id, runner.handicap))
                output.write(
                    "%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s\n"
                    % (
                        market_book.market_id,
                        market_book.publish_time,
                        market_book.status,
                        market_book.inplay,
                        market_book.total_matched,
                        runner.selection_id,
                        runner.ex.available_to_back[0].price,
                        runner.ex.available_to_back[0].size,
                        runner.ex.available_to_lay[0].price,
                        runner.ex.available_to_lay[0].size,
                        runner.total_matched,
                        runner.last_price_traded or "",
                    )
                )

text:
1. Ah I see it is suspended in the UK, I have an account from the Netherlands and it is working fine right now. 
2. As far as commission goes, it is very similar from Betfair. You pay for the net winnings in the market, or am I missing something here?
3. Can you elaborate why? Where can I read about this?

elements.text: Ah I see it is suspended in the UK, I have an account from the Netherlands and it is working fine right now.
As far as commission goes, it is very similar from Betfair. You pay for the net winnings in the market, or am I missing something here?
Can you elaborate why? Where can I read about this?

> 6.5 A Member who meets or exceeds the Thresholds (as defined below) may be charged one or a combination of the MB Rates which only apply to the Exchange and they are as follows:
> Commission rate up to 3.5% per bet (âTransactional Rateâ); or
> Commission rate up to 5% of Gross Profit per market (âMarket Commission Rateâ); and/or
> Revenue share commission rate up to 60% of Net Profits per calendar month (âRevenue Shareâ).
> Â (which shall severally and jointly be referred to as the âMB Ratesâ).
> 6.6 The thresholds are as follows:
> $1,000,000 (one million US Dollars) of Betting Volume; and/or
> $20,000 (twenty thousand US Dollars) of Betting Profits
> (which shall severally and jointly be referred to as the âThresholdsâ).

text: Matchbook is backed by Zjelko and runs at around 5-10% of the volume of Betfair (at least in the racing markets I was looking at). My view is that it wouldn't be worth it unless you were fully automated with a winning system (running on Betfair)
